item.title: What Gibbsian Statistical Mechanics Says: Defending Bare Probabilism
item.description: arXiv:2407.13875v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: I expound and defend the ``bare probabilism'' reading of Gibbsian (i.e. mainstream) statistical mechanics, responding to Frigg and Werndl's recent (BJPS 72 (2021), 105-129) plea: ``can somebody please say what Gibbsian statistical mechanics says?''
item.dc:creator: David Wallace

item.title: Symmetries as Isomorphisms
item.description: arXiv:2407.14234v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Symmetries and isomorphisms play similar conceptual roles when we consider how models represent physical situations, but they are formally distinct, as two models related by symmetries are not typically isomorphic. I offer a rigorous categorical strategy that formulate symmetries as isomorphisms between models and apply it to classical electromagnetism, and evaluate its philosophical significance in relation to the recent debate between `sophistication' and `reduction'. In addition to traditional spacetime models, I also consider algebraic models, in which case we can use the method of natural operators to address the problem of ontological nonperspicuity faced by the categorical strategy. Finally, I briefly expound on the significance of symmetries as isomorphisms in the framework of Univalent Foundations, in which isomorphic structures are formally identified.
item.dc:creator: Lu Chen

item.title: Univalence and Ontic Structuralism
item.description: arXiv:2407.14238v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The persistent challenge of formulating ontic structuralism in a rigorous manner, which prioritizes structures over the entities they contain, calls for a transformation of traditional logical frameworks. I argue that Univalent Foundations (UF), which feature the axiom that all isomorphic structures are identical, offer such a foundation and are more attractive than other proposed structuralist frameworks. Furthermore, I delve into the significance in the case of the hole argument and, very briefly, the nature of symmetries.
item.dc:creator: Lu Chen
